post_context: . During this time period, the confirmed number of infections may provide a more accurate representation of the natural characteristics of COVID-19. The parameter α, which is difficult to estimate accurately, has been calculated to range from 0.3 to 0.5 using different methods and data sets. Fortunately, in the SUQC model, an exact value of α is not critical as the reproductive number R=α=g1 is sensitive in parameter optimization, allowing the bias of α to be balanced by g1. Other parameters and initial values are determined by fitting the daily confirmed infections to the model. By solving the model equation using the fourth order Runge-Kutta method with predetermined values, we can calculate the expected daily confirmed infections, denoted as ^C. The loss function is then optimized using the interiorpoint method in MATLAB to infer the parameter values. It has been observed that the inferred parameter values are not significantly affected by the initial values used in the optimization process. It should be noted that the loss function may overweight later observations due to higher cumulative case numbers, and weighted loss functions have been explored to improve the integration of information throughout the epidemic period.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on global public health and the economy. This study was conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, including Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional (ci∂ic), Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais (IFNMG), and Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at Federal University of Minas Gerais. The research focuses on agent-based simulation and epidemic models such as SEIR to understand and address the challenges presented by the pandemic. The article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, with online availability starting on July 7, 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Thus, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the ongoing COVID-19 epidemic. The COVID-19 pandemic, caused by SARS-CoV-2, was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25, 2020, with the country being severely affected since then. As of June 26, 2020, Brazil has reported over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths from COVID-19. Apart from the public health crisis, the virus has impacted various aspects of life including politics, education, economy, social issues, environment, and climate. Implementing strict social distancing measures remains the most effective way to combat the outbreak, as supported by numerous studies and reviews. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying degrees of success, given the complexities of their societies.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The consideration of uncertainties in data is essential in modeling, with each time point allowed to follow a probability distribution based on assumed mean and variance. The lack of data poses a more significant challenge for modellers, as understanding the comparison between confirmed cases and model predictions is crucial in explaining variability. Confirmed cases represent individuals with symptoms who tested positive for COVID-19, while the infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, regardless of symptoms or diagnosis. This discrepancy between data and model predictions is likened to an iceberg, with the tip above the surface symbolizing confirmed cases and the hidden portion representing the unknown infected population, often referred to as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). 

Why is this a concern for modelers? During model calibration, the estimation of important model parameters like the transmission rate b relies on adjusting the model output to match confirmed cases data. This involves discounting the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), from the model prediction using the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed case data. By testing various ratios of r, we can determine a corresponding value for the transmission rate b through data fitting, impacting the basic reproduction number R0, epidemic scale, and peak time. Due to the wide potential range for the case-infection ratio r of COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary significantly, leading to a wide range of model predictions. Nonidentifiability, a concept in modeling literature, arises when multiple combinations of r and b can fit the data well but result in divergent epidemic predictions. Addressing nonidentifiability during model calibration is crucial for the reliability of model predictions. However, conventional nonlinear least squares methods may struggle to detect or resolve this issue due to their basic optimization algorithms. These algorithms aim to find a global minimum in the objective function, but the presence of infinitely many global minima can complicate the process.

text: The median value of R c is 1.629
author: enrique
pre_context: Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, or administrative data, and published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can be challenging during real-time outbreaks of unknown pathogens, like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Another method is to improve inference techniques and model fitting algorithms to reduce confidence or credible intervals. Our approach, using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Baseline predictions for Xi'an and three scenarios were generated using prediction intervals sampled from the posterior distribution. Parameter values and credible intervals are detailed in Table 1. Bayesian inference was based on confirmed cases in Xi'an between January 21 and February 4, 2020, prior to additional control measures initiated on February 7, including increased hospital beds and door-to-door visits. Projections illustrate the potential epidemic in Xi'an if these measures had not been implemented. Figures 4(a) and (b) depict the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Xi'an together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our analysis, if stringent quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases is estimated to reach around 120,000, and the outbreak in Xi'an would likely not be resolved until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with recovery times increasing based on the severity of the illness. In Covasim, different recovery times are assigned to asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases, as detailed in Table 1. Non-critical cases are expected to recover, while critical cases may recover or face the possibility of death, which increases with age (Table 2). Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious one, with a probability of β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7, depending on various factors. The default β value in Covasim was chosen based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were chosen with a 10:2:2:1 ratio to be consistent with various studies and surveys on time use and infections with known contact types. When considering the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population, these weightings aim to reflect the distribution of transmission events in different contact layers without interventions. In the absence of mitigation measures, roughly 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can alter the value of β. Individual infectiousness is allowed to vary based on factors like viral load, which we model with an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load is determined by a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45. Daily viral load influences the per-contact transmission probability (β) for individuals. These concepts are illustrated in Figure 2.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with durations typically increasing based on the severity of the illness. Our model, Covasim, reflects this variability by incorporating different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases, as outlined in Table 1. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age (Table 2).

In terms of transmission and viral dynamics within the host, when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious person, there is a probability of virus transmission (β). In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day per individual, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of about 4-6 days and an R0 of around 2.2-2.7. The specific value can vary based on factors such as population size, age distribution, and others. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was determined through calibration with data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These values were chosen with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. When considering the default β value of 0.016 for a mixed population without different network layers, these weightings provide a close weighted mean. Without interventions, the distribution of transmission events by contact layer is estimated to be approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community in a typical unmitigated transmission scenario. Interventions like physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual factors such as disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness variations are considered in the model using viral load. Studies have shown that viral load peaks around symptom onset and then declines gradually. The model includes two stages of viral load: an initial high stage lasting 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter, followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load values are drawn from a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and a shape parameter of 0.45, based on international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. Daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual each day. The distribution of transmissions between asymptomatic, presymptomatic individuals is displayed in Fig 2 for individuals with default parameter values.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Therefore, users must adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. When incorporating realistic network structures like households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β varies based on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were selected for consistency with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events across contact layers is roughly 30% households, 25% workplaces, 15% schools, and 30% community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, individuals can vary in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness, with differences in infectivity modeled using individual viral load.

Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context:
, which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state.

The daily viral load determines the adjustment of the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. The figure depicting viral loads for a selection of individuals with default parameter values is shown in Fig 2. The distribution of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals may vary depending on the situation, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is affected by the absence of symptoms in the infectious individual [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be altered based on the modeling application or context, acknowledging that some studies have suggested lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
